text: Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Blackish pour with a a tan head. Notes of sweet vanilla, roasty, some licorice, nutty, some toffee, with a medium bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of vanilla, toffee, oatmeal, chocolate and roasted malts. Taste of chocolate, vanilla, weak bourbon, roasted malts and a slight bitter dry end. Pretty good.

On tap at McGillicuddys, Five Corners, Essex Junction, VT.
Though poured into a pint glass, I get whats going on, heres the rest.
The appearance was a pure black color with a thin bar pours kind of slim white head that falls immediately. Stringy sliding lacing.
The aroma blends a roasty sweet coffee to cocoa bean robust combination over subtle roasty vanilla beans. Just a tad of caramel, sly breadiness. Warming lager yeastiness. Touch of dry woody/barrel nose.
The flavor takes all of those previously mentioned aromas to blend and leave a sort of rugged burnt toasty taste to ride along. Sly blended coffee/vanilla/bready/roasty aftertaste rolling into the finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a medium in body with a great sipping quality about it. Moderate carbonation. Yeastiness seems to help control the ebb and flow of the roastiness hitting my tongue, so its fairly smooth.
Overall, damn nice variant of Framinghammer, well worthy of finding again. I need to find bottles of this.
Bottle share @ Hampton Inn pre-DLD 2016. Pour is deep black with a very small tan head. Notes of vanilla extract, bourbon heat, roasted malt, toffee, caramel sauce, and peat.
Brown, medium head, aroma of barrel, whiskey, toffee, vanilla, wood, chocolate, flavor of barrel, whiskey, vanilla, chocolate, toffee, vanilla, medium bodied.

Sampled at the brewery. I seem to love all variations of Framinghammer and this is no exception. The vanilla comes through loud and clear and works really well to complement this already tasty porter. Good stuff!
Draft sample at the source. Dark brown with a beige head. Vanilla, chocolate, boozy, nutty. Sweet and boozy taste. Big body and moderate carbonation.

From notes. Enjoyed at a tasting at Andrews house on August 18. 500 mL bottle. The pour is a medium to dark brown with a thin cream colored head that falls to a thin ring, no lace. This is a lot thinner than I would have ever suspected. The aroma is dark fruit up front, with a nice oak and a good booziness to it. The vanilla is light and one the back end. The vanilla picks up a little more in the flavor, but the roast, dark chocolate and dark fruits really dont let it stand out too crazily. The bourbon is big on the back end. The mouth feel is thin and light. There is a softer carbonation, but its watery. The aftertaste is lingeringly oaky and slightly tainted with vanilla. This is interesting, but definitely not as good as Id hoped.

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $? ][ mini snifter ][ 05.01.16 ] hazy sepia, thin cream ring. Softly lactic nose, watery at same time, odd plant bitterness a la celery. Front palate is roast and cookie dough, light vanilla barely across dusty roast mid. Watery sugar across the finish.
Black pour, smaller head. Huge vanilla and bourbon aroma. Vanilla at the forefront in The taste, roasted malt, light coffee notes. Whiskey ties it all together. Medium body.

Draft. Smooth vanilla, caramel and marshmallow in the nose. The flavor adds a rich dark fruit character that combines with sugary bourbon and creamy vanilla, giving the impression of a boozy yogurt raisin. Lingering bitter cacao at the edges of the tongue. Clean lager finish and incredibly well-hidden ABV make the glass go down much more quickly than it should.

July 24, 2015. On tap at Lord Hobo. 
Black with a small tan head. Aroma is rich milk chocolate, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, light roasted notes. Taste is medium sweet with toffee, caramel, vanilla and bourbon with a light smooth bitter roasted finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. 
Great, rich yet very drinkable.

Bottle from the brewery shop. Poured into a snifter. A very dark, brownish black. Thick frothy tan head settles to a thin lace. Sweet roasty vanilla aromas and flavors. Very smooth. Alcohol is very well masked. Kinda sweet though. Dry bittersweet finish.

Iphonephan (5610) - McLean, Virginia, USA - MAY 1, 2016
From a bottle share at the DC gathering May 1, 2016. It is a clear dark Amber color with a slight head. The Aroma is toffee. The taste is vanillas with cream with barrel Oak
Overtones. Nice

50cl bottle. Medium beige head atop black body with brown edge. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some Bourbon, vanilla. Taste is moderately sweet, vanilla, some caramel, light Bourbon. Medium body, some stickiness.
From a bottle at the DC gathering May 1, 2016. Pours a clear cola with an off white head. Aroma of toffee. Flavors of vanilla and oak. Smooth finish.
Bottle. Clear dark brown color. Aroma of peppery vanilla on a roasty background. Taste is bib, boozy dark fruit, roast, vanilla.

2 oz pour on draft at Jacks Abby. Consumed on 4/21/2016. 2016 release at 10.3% ABV. Dark brownish black with tan head. Aromas of vanilla, chocolate. Tastes of vanilla, dark chocolate, light oak, caramel. Medium body with a dry finish.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown/black with no head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate fill the nose. Flavor was vanilla, chocolate, bourbon booziness, brown sugar. Had some sweetness to mix with the alcohol presence. Full bodied, creamy, soft carbonation, and a bit of alcohol burn to finish.

Bottle thanks to Reynolds314! Pours black with a medium beige head that dissipates quickly to a bubbly ring with decent lacing. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, hints of anise and molasses. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, loads of vanilla, some cocoa, light licorice, roasted malts, bourbon notes fairly prominent as well. Medium body overall. Solid
Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown to black color with a creamy tan head. Huge vanilla in the aroma. Boozy flavor. Not bad.
Bottle thanks to AirForceHops: Poured a black brown with tan. Aroma is very strong vanilla. Taste is very alcohol burning forward, but has a sweet with vanilla side.

Bottle. Black pour with thin just off white head. Aroma is super vanilla forward, lots of sticky bourbon notes, mild chocolate, vanilla. Taste is mildly sweet, nice and mellow, good vanilla flavor. Palate is full bodied,nice silky texture, enjoyable.

Bottle shared at dbarnolds, 10/31/15. Really nice malty aroma with vanilla, chocolate, and bourbon. Brown with a tan head. Excellent flavor. Sweet and smooth. Rather drinkable for a beer of this ABV.

Dégustée en compagnie de David-Samuel. Bière sombre mais laiteuse à la mousse off-white. Arômes de vanille, de porter. On se croirait face à une milk stout tellement cest riche et vanillé. Un important fond de café, qui se fait dabord sentir au nez, nous suit tout au long de la dégustation. La vanille est omniprésente et riche sur un alcool bien dissimulé qui reviennent somme toute dans une attaque du revers par le bourbon. Très agréable mais un peu sucrée pour moi.
Poured from bottle dark cola with a lacey tan head. Aromas of caramel booze chocolate and vanilla. Taste follows with a nice balanced alcohol finish.
Tap @ Pony w James. Black w med-brown head. Nose is sweet slightly boozy vanilla bean. Same palate, warms on the back end. Medium or even heavy mouthfeel especially in the style. Fan.

Aroma: Mild Vanilla, Mild Roasted Chocolate Malts

Appearance: Dark Hue, Passes No Light, Thin Brown Head Ring, Some Lacing

Taste: Vanilla, Dark Roasted Malts, Milk Chocolate, Mildly Boozy

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Mildly Sweet, Mildly Boozy

Thanks to Mr. J! Pours a very dark brown with a rich tan head. The smell is cream, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit. The taste is vanilla, alcohol, cocoa, dark fruit, licorice sending dry and roasty. The body is full with fine carbonation.

Many thanks to Rian for sharing! The beer starts smooth and fresh. Malty nice vanilla-bitter nose. Fresh and smooth. Deep malty with a nice vanilla fresh malty-deep body. Very intense milk-chocolate vanilla malty aroma. Great!
Weiche Vanillenoten, geringe Süße, etwas künstlich wirkend. Die alkoholische und schokoladige Malzigkeit gefällt, brennt aber zum Ende etwas. Nett. 10/9/12/12/9/11

Bottle shared by a friend. Poured a dark black colour with a small tanned head. Leaving a tanned ring. Nose of dark roasted malts, lots of vanilla, oak, sweet bakers chocolate, fudge, caramel, sweet sticky bourbon, campfire, charred oak, full bodied mouthfeel. With subtile sweet bourbon notes in the finish. Very balanced amazing stuff
Bottle..Pour is black with a bubbly tan head..Nose is vanilla, chocolate, brownie, spice,..Taste is vanilla, very nice balance, fudge, spice, chewy..

Bottle sample at a tasting at Alexeys place. Thanks Ariel. Black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, licorice. Sweet flavor with vanilla, caramel, chocolate, some booziness, and a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. A bit too boozy.
Black pour from 16oz (I think?) bottle at Lakehouse. Tan head. Vanilla bourbon flavor. Fig and grapes. Good shit

Black pour, small of white to espresso head. Nice vanilla and roast on the nose, with some background booze as expected. Flavor follows with just the right balance of roast and vanilla. Really enjoyed this one.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is deep brown with a big tan head and and sticky lacing. Fresh vanilla beans, graham crackers, roasted malt, caramelly, bourbon notes, some coconut, raisins, and oak in the aroma. Taste is dark cocoa, vanilla beans, caramel, some coffee, bourbon, lactose, milk chocolate, marshmallows, and raisins with a rich finish. Full mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Nice Baltic porter.
Great example of what a solid barrel and flavored beer can be. Aroma had the light notes of vanilla and sugar. The mouth is rich thick and heavy. Color is deep black. Tap
Pours the part, mild vanilla nose. Taste continues but subdued. Mild chocolate, and roasted malt. Medium silky body.

Bottle shared by Joes & Judyvv @ "Zunt Om Nog Langer Te Bewaren" tasting (ZONLTB). Opaque dark brown color, small off-white head. Aroma is malts, dark chocolate, vanilla. Taste malts, dark chocolate, vanilla, decently bitter with a nice sweet touch from the bourbon, liquor, light roast. Not super lovely but pretty interesting. Vanilla lovers will dig this though.

Bottle @ SONLTB tasting. Dark brown to black colour with a small beige head. Smells quite sweet, chocolate, cocoa, vanilla. Tastes vanilla, roasty, sweet, lovely, coffee, deep, nice. Full body, soft carbo, nice.

Brown-black body, thin tan head, spotty lacing. Nose has some sharpie, vanilla bean, light roast, oak, and bittersweet chocolate. Medium bodied, moderate sweetness, lingering finish, smooth carbonation throughout

Pours a black from a bottle with a toffee-colored head, minimal lacing. Aroma is of vanilla, oaky, burnt toffee, flavor is bourbon, chocolate, vanilla. Lots of alcohol burn, almost off-putting, but very similar to bourbon overall. Good beer.

.5 liter into a glass. Pours a thick syrupy black, muddled in brown tar and molasses. Lacing is creamy tan and all over, head is average and encompassing. Aroma of vanilla coffee bean, bourbon cascades, chocolate bar, dark malts, raisins, hoppy lingerings. Taste of dry vanilla coffee, dark choco, bourbon vessels, vanilla shake, oak trodden wood, and fun spastic brown sugar cubes. Abv is in and out the whole time, gliding smooth then knocking one down. A deep, hearty and solid brew, good for soul searching, sharing, or moderate ingestion. Memorable.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with light creme colored head. Mouthfeel is a bit light for the style. Mild bourbon heat and vanilla. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml bottle pours a dark brown color without much head. Low carbonation. Nice vanilla flavor, but noticeably harsh alcohol.

Bottle - Thinner black pour with mocha head and little retention. Typical metallic porter nose with a hint of vanilla. Taste follows the nose. Thinner on the palate with a semi dry finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

rate #993; bottle from phatdog1. held this back; loved the regular version (4.4 rate) but rated this much lower which is odd, thought I would enjoy more with the vanilla. not sure if it is me or ?? but bourbon in aroma and taste ruined this for me - just overpowered everything...

Bottle - Rich milk chocolate with a nice sweetness. Deep jet brown and no head. Lots of milk chocolate, sweetness and well balanced. No booze notices and very creamy on the palate. Vanilla was not really prominent although lots of sweet notes.

A- an opaque mahogany pour with cola edges. No head or lacing to write home about.

S- it easily draws comparisons to BA Framinghammer with vanilla added. Some oak, vanilla, coffee and chocolate notes start off. Raisin bread, clay, tangy cacao, rhubarb, roots, brown sugar and molasses create a solid presence. Mild morning after bonfire and clean green pepper. A little bit of fire roasted marshmallow. 

M- medium oily body like all Framinghammers. Alcohol is well hidden. 

T- vanilla beans are proud and prominent from the get go. Chocolate is dry and somewhat secondary but not to be outdone. Earth notes are strong in the middle. Oak and dried fruits show up fashionably late and welcomed. Some herbal and vegetal notes follow, like green pepper, grass and tarragon. Ending is on the dry side with bakers chocolate, more grasses and light licorice.

Bottle shared by Michael - thanks! Clear cola color. No head. Coconut, chocolate, vanilla beans, alcohol, toast. Sweet, rich, boozy, warming. Overall: compared to earlier vanilla beer, this is surprisingly a bit harsh. Still, Id drink this again. Almost perfumey at times?

Bottle that I took to RBSDG at the Dad Pad. Pours a deep black with thin tan head. Roast and cocoa on the nose, a bit of vanilla and touches of wood. Medium bodied, warm vanilla and soft roast. Smooth and long lingering tannins with gentle roast and cocoa. Long and warm. Yummy.

Bottle generously shared by my friend Dave. Pours just about black with a tan head. Very pleasant aroma that is ample vanilla, bourbon, oak, and lightly roasted malt. The flavor is vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, oak, lightly roasted malt, just a bit of molasses. There is some alcohol heat at the finish, but that only serves to intensify the flavor. Fairly well-rounded mouthfeel. Excellent.
Bottle. A smoother, less boozy version of barrel framinghammer. Creamy mouthfeel with a bitter finish. Great.

Bottle. Pretty much identical to the normal barrel aged Framinghammer but with some light vanilla bean notes in the aftertaste. The vanilla takes a little edge off the booziness of the base. Still very good.
Black pour, brown head. Huge aroma of chocolate and oak. Flavor is amazing chocolate, oak, brown sugar, and huge intense vanilla sweet finish. Amazing beer.
Bottle, brown pour, tan head, nose and taste are both coffee but the vanilla smooths it out

Comme le reste de la série, un corps visqueux et svelte mais riche en saveur. Vanille puissante, dominante et fraiche qui na dégal que le volet chocolaté. Lalcool goûte mais la chaleur ny est pas. Fantastique version.

[ Bottle ][ 500mL ][ Ernesto987 ][ Bonus ][ Mini Globe ][ 10.4.14 ]
>> Clear deep cola brown pour, tan foam. Big barrel nose, fumey bourbon, soy, cherry cola, flash of mushroom. Taste is rich bourbon, brown sugar, warming alcohol, flash of mushroom. Palate is fairly bitter, earth, soil, black tea. Rich, barrel forward. Quite nice.

Bottle @ GTs Cat Cabana. Thanks, GT. Black pour with a small khaki head. Really nice combination of vanilla, cocoa, and nice roasted aroma. Slight nuttiness, a bit of coffee, burnt sugar, and dark chocolate. The flavor has a nice mix of chocolate, vanilla, and sugar cookie. A lot of roast and coffee, too. Slight roasty bitterness.

Pour from a bottle is a nice black with a tan colored head aroma is a little boozy but has notes of a smooth vanilla. Taste is a malty with hints of vanilla and coffee. Leaves a dry after taste with a little licorice taste.

Bottle. Pours near black with a beige head. Lighter roasted malts, a solid hit of vanilla, and not too much sweetness. Theres a great balance between the roasted notes and the vanilla sweetness that provides great drinkability, like when you add just the perfect amount of cream to your coffee. Good stuff.

(500ml bottle) medium brown, soapy tan bubbles. Nose of vanilla, chocolate malt, maple, french toast, toasty, oak. Taste is rich, vanilla, toasty, french toast, caramel, burnt sugar. Medium thick body, chocolaty linger.
Bottle shared by a friend. Darkest brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon and chocolate. Malty flavor with vanilla and bourbon before a chocolate and vanilla finish.

Bottle at RBSDADG 2014, courtesy of Jay I believe. Pours a deep brownish black body with thin brown lacing. Aroma is rich vanilla bean, sweet chocolate, soft roast and coconut. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, really delicious vanilla, coconut, butter and chocolate working very nicely together. Almost dont believe this is 10% - a well-crafted decadent porter.

Bottle... Pours hazy and dark brown. The bouquet is an opulent fusion of vanilla, mocha and whiskey. Medium to full-bodied with a skim-milk mouthfeel and reserved carbonation. The flavor is a burnt, bitter intermingling of dark, un-Dutched chocolate, deeply-roasted coffee and whiskey. Lengthy charcoal and whiskey finish. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

I brought the whole 2012 set to our monthly tasting. 


A - Pours jet black with a decent one finger tall tan head, slowly dissipating down to a light film, leaving small webs of lace down the sides of the glass. 


S - Smells of strong vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, oak, coconut, coffee and smoked dark malt. The vanilla is strong, but not as strong as the coffee version is, while still being well balanced. 


T - Starts off with plenty of sweetness from the vanilla and chocolate malt slowly being joined by the dark roast, day old coffee, toasted coconut, cream and warming woody bourbon. Finish is pretty roasty with some nice vanilla sweetness, lingering long after the finish.


M - Heavy body with moderate carbonation. Smooth, sweet feel with some mild roastiness to balance it out. A bit of booze creeps in as it warms up but it never gets in the way of the other flavors.


O - It is tough for me to choose between this one and the coffee, I give the slightest edge to the coffee because it integrates so well with the other flavors but this one is just as good. I would love to have this one again in the future.

Bottle; I Had this one after the "Regular" Barrel Aged variant. I found the labeling confusing. Going into it, I expected this to be a vanilla bean version of the regular (non barrel aged) default beer. I guess Vanilla Barrel-Aged Framinghammer doesnt fit :) But I get it now. The nose is chocolate morsel, mild astringent, with a strong vanilla presence and light brown sugar. I found the additional sweet vanilla character to impact this bourbon barrel variant negatively. I say negatively light, but I found the regular barrel aged version to feel nearly perfect for the style. The additional vanilla over powers the nuances somewhat, but either way : Chocolate, light bittering hop presence, moves to velvet grain, light brown sugar, vanilla syrup , light smoke, and a very light barrel presence. I highly enjoyed trying this beer

Roasted malt. Vanilla. Toffee. Dark toast. Pours solid black with a thick lasting dark tan head. Bourbon. Vanilla. Smooth hard candy texture. Sweet. Light to medium bodied. So smooth with a slight gentle warmth in the throat. Excellent.
500 ml. bottle. Pours a very dark black with a nice tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste is roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate, bourbon, wood, and a touch of coffee. Very nice.

Bottle: Thanks, Alex. Black, deep brown edges & a khaki tinted head that recedes quickly to a foamy collar. Aroma is lightly boozy with notes of roasted malt, faint vanilla, a touch of wood, & some timid chocolate. Taste is heavier on the milky cocoa side with lightly sweet vanilla behind it. The chocolate is actually stronger than the vanilla, in this "vanilla" porter. Burnt caramel malt, faint roast, strong & velvety finish with a commanding but not overly harsh boozy presence. Similar body to the other Framinghammer porters, medium & lightly creamy. An extremely solid beer, for sure, but definitely a few steps behind the original Barrel-Aged & Coffee variants.

Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Dark brown pour with very little head. Aroma is packed with vanilla. Just hints of roast, campfire, and chocolate. Tastes like vanilla ice cream mixed burnt wood and coffee. Some light chocolate in the finish. Finish is a little rough and slightly boozy. My least favorite of the Framinghammers. Great vanilla aroma and taste but for some reason this was not nearly as smooth as the others. Still enjoyed it overall though.

Bottle split at Bruces pad, big thanks to Leighton for another one in this series of goodness, 12/05/14.
Black with a moderate tan swirl clearing to edgework.
Nose is roast malt, chocolate, light spice, light vanilla essence, puff of smoke.
Taste comprises much the same, solid robust Baltic Porter with a rub of vanilla.
Medium + bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Another decent offering from this series.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of light-moderate vanilla, chocolate, molasses, and light coffee. It pours a dark brown with some faint orange highlights and a small soapy light brown head. The flavor starts with chocolate, caramel, and light molasses. The finish has light-moderate vanilla with a somewhat light roasted coffee.

Pours a dark brown, nearly black. Small beige head. Aromas of booze....light roasted malt and faint vanilla. Taste is thin, boozy and unbalanced. A bit disappointed, actually. The base beer is too far in the background here. The oak and bourbon dominate, leaving the middle ground muted. I wish there was a bit more body to this one.
Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a cloudy brown with beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong vanilla, roast, oak. Medium mouthfeel with sweet vanilla, light roast, hides alcohol well. Very good.
draft at Tap & Mallet, best of the bunch IMO. medium bodied black pour. smooth cohesive bourbon & vanilla flavors. solid roastiness, dark chocolate. very nice

12th May 2014Tasting at Bruces pad. Thanks to Leighton. Opaque.dark brown beer, little tan head. Airy palate, light fine carbonation. Airy lght dark malts. Nice light vanilla ice cream. Light minerals. Finishes light. Nicely joined up. Strange how a little vanilla just lightens everything.

Sampled this at Tap and Mallet total tap takeover. Dark brown, thin beige head. Sweet vanilla bean, coffee roast, milk chocolate, brown sugar, and bourbon. Sweetness of the vanilla is countered by a dense wood flavor. A little more than medium bodied. Finishes with a little booziness.
Whoa . This was hot, and not much notes of a baltic porter. I was not impressed, and this was supposed to be one of the best of the group. And satisfied my curiosity to try any more of these.

Bottle acquired via trade from ClarkVV. Thanks, dude! Pours a nice darker blackish brown hue, not opaque but dark enough. Brownish lighter glow on the edges shows a bit. Frothy tannish / light brown head hybrid meets with gentle stick around. Aromas are decent vanilla bean, touches of roast and mellow cocoa, faint coffee elements. Mellow oak grows a bit, subtle spirits, touches of caramel, biscuit and mellow brown sugar. The vanilla bean is present but not overwhelming or done to death. Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a bit heavier. Touches of bitterness and roast meet some decent smoothed out vanilla, touches of cocoa flourish, some biscuit and mellow spirit cling. Middle shows a touch more body but still a bit thinner overall. Some smoothness, creamy vanilla hits as we start to taper out. Oak and barrel element seems well integrated, not hot. Perhaps the base just isnt that full to begin with as Im not getting any offensive or overdone barrel elements. Finish is dry, a bit tannic and flavorful, decent vanilla and gentle roast, touches of oak and cocoa, coffee elements hold together. Solid stuff.

Bottle shared by b3shine. Poured a dark brown color with a large light brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Good roasted coffee, vanilla and chocolate aroma. Medium to full body with a dry smooth texture and flat carbonation. Well balanced vanilla sweet toasted malt flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Very good porter.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 Bottle thanks to Leighton. It pours near black with a small tan head. The nose is fresh, roasty, toast, cocoa, milk choc, toffee, treacle and rocky road. The taste is rich, roasted malt, sweet, candy, treacle, milky choc, candy, vanilla, intense sweetness, touch of alcohol warmth and dirt with a dry, sweet finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. A bit sweet for my liking.

Bottle shared in London - picked up at the brewery. Pours clear, deep brown with a frothy, tan head. The nose has lots of dark bread, some chocolate, light roast. Medium sweet flavor with further sugary, dark bread, milk chocolate, slight vanilla extract, hints of burnt earth. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with a bit of charred toast, further vanilla, cocoa, dark chocolate. Solid.
Sweet and thick. Bourbon aroma and flavor that dominates everything, far too much bourbon character for me.

Bottle from Liquors 44. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Doesnt leave much lacing in the glass. Has a big licorice nose. I get a touch of the vanilla on the tongue but its more licorice booze than anything. Eh!

500 ml bottle shared by b3shine. Pours dark cola brown in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have rich roasted malts, big vanilla, caramel, chocolate, bourbon, wood, coconut, light coffee and earth. Medium bodied, lasting finish. Very good, but not blown away.

At my place over an empty pool with group. Pours black with circle of white head. Aroma is huge vanilla with bourbon barrell, smooth tasty lightly roasted malt. Taste is by vanilla and more vanilla, and smooth bourbon barrel. Fantastic beer, but not quite as drinkable as regular due to so much vanilla; but better than regular due to so much more flavor.
Pours a nice black oil like with off-white head. Vanilla, barrel, and chocolate on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes sweet.

500ml bottle, thanks to b3shine for sharing. Tasted right after trying reg BA framing, and coffee framing. Clear brown red color, Thin ring of khaki head, kind of bubbly. Less of a potent nose than the other versions, mild vanilla in the nose. More vanilla in the flavor. Moderate to bigger sweet taste, moderate bitter, very light heat in the finish. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Awesome barrel-aged variant of this fantastic baltic porter. Seems like it has just a bit more of a bite than the other versions I tried, though.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the group). Looks good; a translucent dark brown with beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells good too; dark malt, oak, and vanilla. Tastes like it smells, but not quite as robust. Nice and smooth on the palate. Great beer; the best of the BA versions in my opinion.

This one poured a darker brown with a beige head. Aroma was of light chocolate, vanilla nd some metalic notes. Flavor was similar, some strange vegetal notes and vanilla, not much of an underlying beer. Disappointing.
Bottle shared by Bobby. Pours black with brown head. Nose/taste of vanilla bean, bourbon, oak, chocolate, toasted oats, coffee and milk chocolate. Medium body.
50cl bottle side by side with the Coffee version. Pours an oily, opaque black with some cloudy white head. Nose has lots of vanilla, green coffee. Flavor is vanilla and caramel. Not great.
Bottle shared during DLD in line for our bottles. Pours a deep dark brown black. Aroma of vanilla. Interesting bitter-sweet thing going on. Not my favorite.

Pour is dark brown, almost black, caramel to light brown head. Nose smells like it was barrel aged, wood and bourbon notes up front with a pleasant light roast and some rich malt goodness. A bit of caramel and some chocolate cake notes with just a hint of vanilla. Flavor has bourbon up front, quite nicely balanced. More vanilla in the flavor, well carbonated, some fudge notes and touches of caramel. Never gets sweet, has a light roastiness through the finish. Good stuff!
Bottle tasted at DLD. Aroma of vanilla. Light carb med bod. Pretty bitter taste
Bottle shared by Skyview. Pours dark, aroma is sweet vanilla and chocolate. Taste is vanilla all over. Really creamy and smooth, slightly cloying but I like it. Love the vanilla on this.

16.9 oz bottle. Dark brown with a bubbly tan head. Nose is coffee, peanut and fig with hints of vanilla. Creamy medium body with a sharp tang. Taste is coffee, bitter licorice, bourbon kind of masking the vanilla and Bakers chocolate. Pretty boozy.

Delicious. Nice aroma. Mellow with little bite. Great. A little more vanilla would be perfect. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy by Me
Clear chestnut brown pour, very little head. Nice vanilla, bourbon, oak, toffee, chocolate, some alcohol warmth Smooth and nice.

Bottle (thanks to Reynolds314 for this one)... Poured jet black with a moderate light tan/khaki head. Aroma of roasted grains, char, and vanilla. Vanilla was very forward here with a nice roasted malt tone. Dark, burnt sugars and other sweet characters disguised the higher abv nicely.

Bottle and served in snifter: Pours a very deep brown, near opaque with a nice lasting frothy tan head and good lace. The aroma has intense vapours of sweet bourbon, vanilla bean, chocolate covered raisin, roasted coffee, fig newtons, a touch of ashy, tobacco and leathery earthiness. The taste is moderately sweet and chocolaty with the vanilla kicking it towards the finish. Just a tad piney hops still running here and there along with light handed dark fruit notes (this is something I would have like to seen more of). Smooth, lush and oily mouth feel hiding most of the 10% ABV, most not all. Overall this is a nice treat as snow is falling two days after it was nearly 80 degrees.
Bottle shared at LeviLOL tasting. Chocolate and vanilla nose. Brown pour with a tan head. Holy vanilla batman! Like a white chocolate vanilla slap in the face. Really nice.
Bottle shared by Bob - thanks! Wood, big vanilla, chocolate - oily smooth. Damn, this is good stuff!

Pours mahogany tinged black into an English pint. Mocha head with excellent retention recedes to coat surface. Dark chocolate, vanilla and oak aromas. Thick with dark caramel, dusty cocoa and ripe fruit upfront turning sharp and oaken before a bitter, lasting hot chocolate molasses finish.

My Bottom Line:
This silky Barrel-Aged Baltic Porter offers sultry vanilla notes over coffee-like roastiness and sweet chocolate in a rich mouthfeel.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam laces atop the ebony.
-The low carbonation tends to make the body feel bigger.
-Complexity may not be this beers strong suit, but it remains a smashing dessert brew.
-Bourbon and vanilla are obviously very harmonious.

Bottle.

A deep dark stout with a thin brown head. In aroma, sweet fruity grassy chocolate malt with herbal hops, vanilla extract, complex yet pleasing. On mouth, a sweet fruity chocolate malt with coffee grind, mocha, vanilla cookies, oily mouth feel, delicious.

500ml bottle thanks to NHhophead! Pours dark oily brown-black with tiny thin tan head. Nose is rich bakers chocolate, coffee, raisin, vanilla, subtle bourbon. Taste is bourbony fruit, dark chocolate covered raisins, vanilla extract. Finish is bitter roasty fruity bourbon, dark chocolate, coffee, lasting vanilla. Very good.

Sampled @ RBNEG. Dont recall who brought it, but a big thanks. Pours black with a mocha colored head. Roasted malt and vanilla bean nose with a hint of bourbon. Flavor is a blend of chocolate malt, oak, vanilla and bourbon. Smooth palate with a body towards the full side. Good stuff.

Bottle from Andover Liquors,
solid black color with a smallish tightly bubbled tan head that quickly dissipates to wisps of foam on top. Aromas of chocolate chip cookie dough dominate with hints of brown sugar, earthy oak and a touch of alcohol. The flavor is sweet chocolate and vanilla frosting up front but the barrel wood and spirits come in quickly to squash that. The finish is a lingering brown sugar roasted grain and vanilla affair. Medium to thick body with a light to moderate level of carbonation and a sweet creamy silky syrupy mouthfeel. I love this beer! Complex clean and extremely flavorful. Too bad there wasnt more than one on the shelf when I was shopping!
GOOD! Ill rate later. Vanillin meets cookie dough. Lethal aroma of cigarette smoke, leather, and burnt leather.

Bread, vanilla, caramel, and a fair amount of booze in the aroma. Flavor starts sweet, with chocolate, vanilla, wood, and nuts. Some coffee/chocolate bitterness in the flavor, along with some whiskey/bourbon alcohol. Not my favorite style--I like beer, not bourbon--but not as over the top as some of the other barrel aged beers and really a pretty solid choice for a cold night nightcap.

2014 vintage into a snifter. Pours a dark black with a finger of light khaki foam. Nice lacing. Aroma is milk chocolate and sweet vanilla beans. A touch of roasted malts and oak. Taste is milk chocolate into a very sweet wall of vanilla. Its coating and thick and detracts from any other notes. Cant say I get any bourbon notes other then some alcohol heat and a light char on the finish. Smooth and creamy yet still thin enough to feel like a porter. Overall this was the worst of the variants for me. The vanilla, although tasting genuine, was just too much and too sweet despite the relative thinness of the base beer.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2014 2014 bottle, drunk 2/16/14Dark mahogany with some lighter auburn tints. Great clarity, not opaque by any means. Light beige head is small and recedes fairly rapidly to cover, with moderate lacing.Coconut, alcohol, corn and light vanilla in the nose. Phew, they arent messin around with the bourbon barrel here. Stuff is pretty raw. Must be a very new barrel, first or second use at most. The booziness burns off quickly, at least and youre left with just a ton of bourbon. Maybe a touch of chocolate and lightly sweet maltiness in the background but no roastiness really breaks through the bourbon dominance. After some more warming and breathing, I do begin to get some light coffee notes and a touch of dark roast.In the mouth, Im actually surprised by how much less bourbon dominance there is. Dark chocolate and roastiness are forward with a very light vanilla sweetness and some more coconut, but none of the expected graininess or harshness from overdone barrel character. Alcohol is present and warming but not terribly overt. Soft, slick mouthfeel and a medium-light body. Nice balance of sweetness and roast. Tends sweeter with the vanilla exacerbating this a bit, but by no means is the vanilla overdone. Retronasal hoppiness is lightly piney and only moderately bitter. Carbonation is light, but not too light; does help break up the sweetness a bit. Overall, the aroma is too much like a whiff of chocolate bourbon and theres too much alcohol warmth on the finish. Yes, as a sipper, its certainly tolerable and enjoyable, but to me its just too many forceful flavors competing with too light of a body. Dont see why this couldnt be in the 7% abv range and be every bit as flavorful.

Dark brown, thin beige head. Sweet vanilla bean, coffee roast, milk chocolate, brown sugar, and bourbon-soaked oak. Sweetness of the vanilla is countered by a pronounced wood flavor. A little more than medium-bodied but not by much. Finishes on a somewhat herbal note with a little booziness.

Poured from bottle into tulip: Pours brown / black with a thin head. Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, toffee, caramel. Flavor is more of the same. Medium to heavy body, smooth finish, not overly sweet like some barrel-aged beers can get and is really well balanced. Nicely done!
Draft at the source. Pours black coffee brown with a beige head that rings the glass. Aroma is dark chocolate and vanilla. This is quite sweet, caramel, fig, soy, and lots of vanilla.
Beautiful dark, vanilla, and robust smell. Absolutely wonderful porter with a tasty bourbon flavor up front and finishes with a great subtle vanilla taste. Can't wait to get more.

500ml bottle in a tulip. Pours black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, some vanilla, chocolate, bourbon and oak, a little dough, and some light spices. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Smooth texture. A good beer - definitely worth trying.

Better than Bomb with none of the hype. Pours a translucent black/brown pour with small tan head. Aroma is vanilla, cocoa, bourbon, and toffee. Taste is mildly sweet with a drying bourbon filled finish and really balanced vanilla quality.
Bottle, its a good flavor. I dont like vanilla in beer and its a little overwhelming, adds a sweetness I think when I like dry

Nearly black body, sides are translucent. Hefty tan head. 

Poured alongside the regular (bourbon?) BA Framinghammer. Easily smell the vanilla amidst the dry yeast. Chocolate, mild booze, roasty malt. Any rough edges get smoothed out by the silky vanilla. Damn tasty.

Pours a rich burnt umber color with a finger of mocha foam. Lots of chocolate syrup, medium roast, smooth vanilla bean and a touch of bourbon and licorice. The palate follows with a smooth creamy mouthfeel and a long chocolate cake with a nice dose of vanilla and bourbon to round it all out. Tasty stuff and looking forward to the next release so I can try this fresh out of the barrel !

The beer is opaque and near black with a half inch of mocha colored head. Outstanding aroma, featuring vanilla beans, oak, booze, coffee, dark chocolate. The vanilla bean character really begins to emerge as the beer is allowed to warm. Absolutely delicious. So much going on here. Complex and wonderful. Medium to full bodied with relatively low carbonation. Smooth on the palate with minimal alcohol presence. A terrific beer. I would love to have this again.

500 ml bottle shared by bsuedekum- thanks again, Blake! Looks the same as the bourbon barrel version- deep coffee brown with a smallish beige head. Vanilla is immediately apparent in the nose, which also features chocolate, molasses, oak, nuts, and tobacco. Flavor hits all the same notes. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, sticky mouthfeel. A little thinner than the bourbon barrel version, but marginally better.
Nice variation of this brew, the vanilla almsot makes it creamy a true delight.
Bottle shared by Seth. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Wonderful vanilla nose. Huge vanilla, dark roasted malts, and brown sugar notes. Very good mouthfeel with a good body.

16oz bottle or whatever size it was. Poured a black color with the consistency of cola with a medium-tan head. Aroma was sweet malts with plenty of roasted character, vanilla is there. Alcohol is rounded out quite a bit. Quite good.
Bottle. Alcohol and chocolate malt aroma. Brown with small head. Sweet brown sugar/chocolate malt flavor with light alcohol finish. Smells pretty boozy but tastes great - nice and smooth.

Bottle courtesy of AirForceHops. Sweet lactic chocolate, vanilla, boozy oak aroma. Black with a moderate creamy, quickly dissipating tan head. Follows the nose - sweet lactic chocolate, roasty malt, vanilla, spicy oak, and alcohol flavor.  Medium full body, soft carbonation.  Very nice. I think I like the coffee version the best - it seemed to have just a little more complexity.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. No vanilla aroma to speak of, small bit sweeter though. Flavor is a bunch of vanilla with some malt tones, even though it isnt, vanilla seems artificial.

Pours and looks just like the other Framinghammer variants. Thanks to my buddy chris for grabbing one for me. Nose is still a hint of coffee, oak and vanilla sweetness. Sweet, tobacco, smoke and leather. Very musty sort of taste and the vanilla doesnt make it any better. Its a good baltic porter but the coffee version is the clear winner.

Received from Allen, thanks a bunch for the awesome box! Pours black in color with hues of brown around the edges of the glass. Nose is malty with some tootsie roll chocolate in the background. Not much in terms of barrel in the nose. The tootsie roll chocolate persists in the flavor and has a significant amount of vanilla bean and malt as well. Moderate mouthfeel, some booziness, light carbonation, and a moderate finish. Nice beer, vanilla might be a little overpowering in comparison to the base beer though.

bottle share at hill farmsteads pre-3rd anniversary. pours almost black with small but creamy light beige head, some retention and nice lacing. vanilla and oak (!), roasted malts and nuts, dark fruitiness, caramelized nuts and almost burnt brown sugar, some sweetness, almost cloying though. average to soft carbonation, medium to full body - sticky and oily. a nice BA baltic porter for sure. hail to lagers - much enjoyed it.

Bottle (500 ml). Thanks to the guy who brought this at Hill Farmstead pre-3rd anniversary bottle share. Black with a medium creamy brown head, good retention, and good lacing. Aroma is mainly of vanilla with bourbon, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Taste is moderately sweet with a ton of vanilla in there, bourbon, caramel, roasted malt, chocolate and cereals. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Rich Baltic Porter dominated by intense vanilla presence. Alcohol is well hidden. Solid brew!

I picked up all three barrel aged variations at Julios Liquors on 4 May 2013 for the special release. I am now comparing Side- by Side- by- Side. Insanely dark pour with thin tan head. Massive retention.  Wonderful aromas of bourbon, wet oak, chocolate and burnt malt. The vanilla bean really comes through in the flavor up front. The barrel notes and malts are also there and just as fine as the normal barrel aged Porter. Vanilla is rich and lingers throughout the sip. Blends well with the barrel notes. This is my favorite of the three variations. I could knock this back for hours.

Bottle in Vt. Pour was brownish black with creamy tan head. Solid lacing streaking on my lawsons glass. Aroma was vanilla bean, chocolate, dark roasted malt, and some bread. Flavor was similar.Lots of creamy, sweet notes followed by a roasty long finish. Well executed porter from JAcks Abby. Dangerous at 10percent.
